docs.lead_paragraph: Fearing that Connecticut's public universities will lose up to $70 million a year in Federal aid because of a state ban on military recruiting on campus, lawmakers will consider changing state law at a special session of the Legislature announced today by Gov. John G. Rowland. The session will start Oct. 29 and is expected to last only a few days.

headline.main: Legislators to Consider Letting Military Recruiters on Campuses

docs.abstract: Connecticut legislators, fearing that state's public universities will lose up to $70 million a year in Federal aid because of state ban on military recruiting on campus, will consider changing state law at special session of Legislature announced by Gov John G Rowland (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I'm starting a new political movement. It's called ''Americans Against Voice Mail.'' Why? Because the main reason so many people have lost jobs, been forced to change jobs, or been able to upgrade their jobs in the last tumultuous decade is not a lowering of U.S. trade barriers. It's technology. A Mexican working at 75 cents an hour didn't take the job of our office receptionist; a microchip did -- the one that operates the voice mail device in all our office phones. A Chinese making 75 cents an hour didn't take that auto worker's job; a robot did. A Brazilian making 75 cents an hour didn't take your neighbor's grocery job; a supermarket scanner did.
docs.abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says Congress is on verge of denying Pres Clinton 'fast track' authority he needs to sign free trade agreements with rest of South America, under mistaken impression that free trade is responsible for killing jobs; says technology, not cheap foreign labor, is killing jobs; says every serious economic study indicates that bulf of job loss is produced by technological change and deregulation and only 20 percent can be attributed to freer trade (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One is a epublican, the other a Democrat. One is a conservative, the other a liberal. One is Episcopalian, the other Jewish. One is 61 years old, the other only 44. One is a man of action, a former fighter pilot, the other an intellectual, a former Rhodes scholar. But John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, are both senators, and on one of the salient issues in today's politics, campaign finance, they are partners. Their names are on the bill to overhaul campaign fund-raising that is backed by President Clinton and opposed by members of both parties on Capitol Hill. What is more, they have become fast friends. They and their wives spent a long weekend not long ago swimming, fishing, hiking and cooking out at Mr. McCain's Arizona retreat.

headline.main: Odd Couple Cross Political Lines to Fight System

docs.abstract: Sen John McCain, Republican, and Sen Russell D Feingold, Democrat, are Senate's latest odd couple, co-sponsors of bill to overhaul campaign fund-raising that is backed by Pres Clinton and opposed by members of both parties on Capitol Hill; McCain and Feingold are often at opposite ends of political spectrum, but they share certain suspicion of government spending; both are individualists willing to go against grain of their parties; they have earned enmity of many of their fellow senators, who benefit from status quo; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Sept. 30 news article on nurse practitioners struck a raw nerve. The care that is given by a nurse practitioner cannot be compared to that of a physician. Your article makes it sound as if spending time talking and getting to know patients and educating them on life style changes or exercise programs is a novel idea. It's not! As a physician I have been trained to do this and have been doing it for years. I resent the idea that a patient must seek out a nurse for ''extra attention.''

headline.main: Nurse Practitioners Can't Take Place of Doctors; Physicians Can't Win

docs.abstract: Dr Jan A Koenig letter contends that care that is given by nurse practitioner cannot be compared to that of physician

docs.lead_paragraph: Stop me if you've heard this one. Three doctors are driving in a car; the car goes over a cliff, and all three are killed instantly and go up to heaven. St. Peter greets the first one and asks what she did in her life. ''I was a family doctor, I healed many people and took good care of my patients,'' she says. ''Welcome to heaven, come right in,'' says St. Peter. The second doctor answers, ''I was a cardiologist, and I helped many people with heart trouble to lead healthier lives.'' ''Welcome to heaven, come right in.'' The third doctor says, ''I worked for managed care.'' ''Welcome to heaven,'' St. Peter says. ''Your stay is limited to 24 hours.'' So here I am, a doctor shadowing another doctor, trailing behind her as she goes from exam room to exam room -- something I haven't done since my own medical training. As I try to park myself out of the way, wedged between the wall and the exam table, I feel, immediately, that old medical-student sense that I am once again here to learn important lessons -- and that part of the challenge will be to figure out just what those lessons are supposed to be.
docs.abstract: Perri Klass article on medical practice of Debra Shapiro, internist in Cambridge, Mass, who is an old-fashioned doctor who takes very good care of her patients and at the same time a skilled navigator of complex new world of managed care; photos; Shapiro, who believes in managed care, discusses overcoming bureaucratic hurdles and manipulating rules to obtain most appropriate care for her patients; she observes that most doctors do not understand system, and expresses concern about push to standardize doctors' practices without any attention to individual styles; basic paradox of managed care itself is that way to save money taking care of sick people is to avoid signing up sick people (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the joys of taking a sea cruise with your children is that you can sometimes forget you have them. They tend not to fall overboard, but on a big cruise ship with its limitless possibilities of exploration, they do disappear for long stretches. To my 10-year-old twin boys, Anthony and Paul, the Windward, a Norwegian Cruise Lines ship, was like a floating antimatter universe away from their regular world of home and school and responsibility -- full of freedoms and guilty pleasures and hiding places. Often that newfound independence made them distinctly hard to find. Somewhat paradoxically, though, it also made our vacation much more of a happy family experience than some other trips we've taken, notably the week we spent together boxed inside a tiny motor home in Maine.
docs.abstract: Kirk Johnson article on Caribbean cruise aboard the Windward of Norwegian Cruise Line; reports that ship's immense size, frequent stops and numerous other children provided his ten-year-old twins with lots of independent activity; photos; map (M)
docs.snippet: ONE of the joys of taking a sea cruise with your children is that you can sometimes forget you have them. They tend not to fall overboard, but on a big cruise ship with its limitless possibilities of exploration, they do disappear for long stretches....

docs.lead_paragraph: TWENTY years ago, 2000 seemed so far away that the various government and civic groups that would later be formed to study how to prepare for the millennium had not been thought of yet. It was a time when Westchester was obsessed with its high electric rates and prepared for a public referendum on a plan to oust Con Edison. One of the biggest issues of the day was what to do with the ever-increasing amount of garbage that county residents and businesses generated, because the Croton Landfill was under a long-standing court order to be closed in 1981.

headline.main: Over the Years, Government Has Taken a More Visible Role

docs.abstract: Overview of changes in Westchester County, NY, government since 1977; longtime residents comment on new ways in which government is trying to correct social and economic problems; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Only eight men and women showed up for debate on the floor of the State Assembly. The poor showing was understandable. Just one bill had been posted, and action on the issue would hardly determine anyone's political future. They considered legislation that would mandate a public-education campaign on winter's ''lethal missiles'' -- the hazardous accumulation of snow and ice that can fly from the tops of speeding motor vehicles. After a half hour of give and take, the measure passed and the session was adjourned. The group had argued over the bill's legality, as well as its muscle, just like a bunch of real legislators, but they weren't. They were the State House's new class of tour guides, taking part in a mock session to help them teach the process to the 24,000 people who visit the capitol building each year.
docs.abstract: Article describes mock session of New Jersey State Assembly by new class of tour guides in Trenton in order to help them teach process to visitors to state capitol; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN we were young we thought we would retire to some exotic place,'' said Hugh Appling. ''In the end we went where the children were.'' Mr. Appling is 76; his wife, Mary, is just a bit older. He retired in 1976 as deputy director general of the Foreign Service, but it was not until 1993 that the Applings sold their house in McLean, Va., and bought a condominium at the Jefferson in the rapidly developing Ballston section of Arlington, Va., across the Potomac from Washington.

headline.main: For the Elderly, The High-Rise, High-End Life

docs.abstract: Article discusses growth in Northeastern states in high-rise senior living retirement communities, in which there is independent living for healthy and special medical facilities for infirmed; photo (M)
